A black box in the car ?

American road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the decaying highway system , and believe they have found the solution in a small black box that can be found in the dashboard of every car .

The devices that record every kilometre travelled and report the information to the authorities are at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and the state planning offices to revise the obsolete system of financing US roads .
The normally boring area of road planning has suddenly sparked intense debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have allied themselves with environmental groups and are in favour of the government using small boxes to record the kilometres that have been driven – and possibly where they have been driven – and then using the information to calculate tax certificates . are . .
The Tea Party is appalled .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and raises a number of data protection concerns .
But , while Congress cannot agree on action , several states are no longer waiting .
They are currently considering how to switch over the next ten years to a system where drivers pay per mile .
Thousands of car drivers have already tested the tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS surveillance .
This is really a must for our country .

“ It ’ s nothing we ’ ll use only possibly , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , Managing Director of Southern California Assn. of Government , who plans to record the miles that have been taken by all Californian drivers in the state from 2025 .
The way we pay these taxes will change .
The technology is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , which is financed from taxes , is bankrupt for Americans at the cone .
But America is no longer fucking as much as it used to . .
Cars use less petrol .
The national oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 cents per litre ) has not risen for 20 years .
Politicians do not dare to raise the tax even by one cent at high spray prices .
“ The gas tax is simply not future-proof , ” says Lee Munnich , an expert on transport legislation at the University of Minnesota .
His state recently equiped 500 cars with tachographs to test a mileage based payment system .
“ This is the most sensible long-term alternative , ” he said .
Bureaucrats call it a mile-based user fee .

Not surprisingly , the idea is popular with urban liberals , for example , because the tax could be used to influence driving behavior in such a way as to reduce congestion and climate-damaging exhaust emissions .
California planners rely on the system to develop strategies to achieve the state ’ s ambitious , legally anchored goals on climate change .
But Pennsylvania Republican Bill Shuster , Chairman of the House Transportation Committee , has also stated that he sees it as the most viable long-term alternative .
The free marketers of the Reason Foundation are also fond of the idea of letting drivers pay after the race .
“ This is not a tax that disappears in a black hole , ” explains Adrian Moore , Vice President of Reason ’ s Guidelines .
People pay directly for what they get .
The movement is also supported by two former US transport ministers who , in a 2011 report , asked Congress to move toward mileage-based settlement .
Last year , the US Senate approved a $ 90 million pilot project that would have included 10,000 cars .

But the majority in the House of Representatives prevented the move , responding to the concerns of rural MEPs representing people who often have to travel many miles on their way to work or to the city in everyday life .
Several states and large cities are nonetheless moving in this direction on their own .
Most dedicated is Oregon , which currently recruits 5,000 drivers for the country ’ s largest experiment .
These drivers will soon pay the mileage fees to the state instead of the petroleum tax .
Nevada has already completed a pilot project .
New York City is also considering this .
Illinois is testing it to a limited extent with trucks .

And the I-95 coalition , which includes the transport ministries of 17 states on the east coast ( including Maryland , Pennsylvania , Virginia , and Florida ) , is currently examining how to introduce the change .
The concept is not a universal hit .
In Nevada , where 50 volunteers recently were equipped with the equipment , drivers were skeptical about the idea that the government could follow each of their movements .
“ Concerns against Big Brother and such things were a big problem , ” explains Alauddin Khan , Head of Strategy and Results Management at Nevada ’ s Transport Ministry .
People did not want it .
When the test started , Nevada ’ s ACLU warned on its website : “ It would be relatively easy to turn the tachographs into full-scale surveillance devices . ”
There is no need to build a gigantic , bulky technological infrastructure that would inevitably be used to collect data about the daily movements of individuals .
Nevada is one of a number of states that are now looking for affordable technology that allows the state to capture the kilometres that have been driven , but not exactly when and where .
That , Khan said , would also reassure the public .
Hunting for this technology has led some authorities to a small startup company called True Mileage in California .
Originally , the company did not intervene to help states tax drivers .
Instead , their aim was to establish a foothold in an emerging market for car insurance , in which drivers should pay on the basis of the miles they have travelled .
However , the devices it tests are also interesting for road planners , because they do not work with GPS and provide limited information that is regularly uploaded via modem .
“ People are more willing to participate if their speed and locations are not recorded , ” explained Ryan Morrison , CEO of True Mileage .
Major mistakes have been made in some of these public pilot programmes .
There are much cheaper and less intrusive ways to implement this .
In Oregon , the planners are experimenting with giving drivers a range of choices .
You can choose a device with or without GPS .
Or they choose no device at all and instead pay a flat rate on the basis of the miles travelled on average by all residents of the state .
Others hope to be able to sell the concept of a suspicious public by providing the devices with more functions than with less .

In New York City , traffic officials want to develop a tax device to pay for parking fees , pay insurance only for journeys , and collect speed data from other vehicles in real time , allowing drivers to avoid congestion .
“ Drivers would be motivated to participate by the added value of the benefits offered by the system , ” says a city planning document .
However , some transport planners are wondering whether all the talk about paying per mile is not just a huge distraction .
At the Metropolitan Transportation Commission for the San Francisco Bay area , officials said that Congress could solve the problem of the bankrupt Highway Trust Fund simply by increasing fuel tax .

Esa Chooses Big Space Missions
Far away planets , gravitational waves or black holes - experts from the European Space Agency must now agree on two major projects that they want to start in the coming years .
There were 30 proposals , five are still in the race .
Far worlds .
More than 1000 planets on other stars have already found astronomers .
No one knows whether there is life on at least some of them .
The choice is difficult : Should you search for gravitational waves ?
Or do you prefer to explore the origin of the cosmos ?
Or search for earthy planets and discover perhaps extraterrestrial life ?
These are the questions that are being asked by the European Space Agency Esa .
For their Cosmic Vision program , they are looking for ideas for two major space projects that are intended to drive research forward .
The budget for such " L missions " is about EUR 1 billion each .
The start is expected to be in 2028 and 2034 .
In early September , the elite of European space research met in Paris to discuss proposals for such missions .
There were 30 ideas on the table , five of them coming into the narrower choice .
Numerous bodies review the proposals , check with the researchers .
In the next few days a final decision will be taken by the Scientific Programme Committee .
The Esa has selected four major questions to which the missions of the Cosmic Vision programme , initiated in 2007 , will find answers .
What are the conditions for the formation of planets and life ?
The exact events of the formation of stars from large clouds of gas - and thus the formation of planets surrounding these stars - are still in the proverbial darkness .
A large infrared telescope in space could penetrate this darkness .
And if a star has planets , under what circumstances can life arise there ?
To address this question , the space telescope " Cheops " will be launched in 2017 , which will examine more closely the 500 already known planetary systems in our vicinity .
But the possibilities are limited , Cheops is a small mission with a budget of EUR 150 million .

With larger instruments , astronomers could map earthly planets and even analyze the composition of their atmospheres , searching for " biomarkers " : gases that are considered an indication of biological activity .
How does the solar system work ?
This question , too , should ultimately provide information on the conditions for the creation of life .
The magnetic activity of a star and the interaction of its magnetic field and the particle radiation emitted by it with the planetary system play an important role .
In our solar system , these processes can be examined exemplarily .
With the " Solar Orbiter " , Esa has already approved a M-class mission ( there the budget is about half a billion euros ) for this question .
The probe should start in 2017 and observe the surface and activity of the sun closely .
Jupiter and his moons are of great interest to the researchers .
They want to find out what role the giant planet played in the development of the solar system .
The Esa provides for the first of the three L missions of the Cosmic Vision program .
The probe " Juice " ( Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ) is scheduled to start its journey in 2022 .
Eight years later , she reaches Jupiter to study the atmosphere of the planet and the icy moons of Europe , Kallisto and Ganymed .
What are the basic physical laws of the universe ?
The universe offers many possibilities to study matter under extreme conditions and to examine whether the laws of nature known to us are still valid there .
There may also be deviations that could guide the physicists toward a new theory , under which all known laws of nature can be combined .
How did the universe come about and what does it consist of ?
13.7 billion years ago , our cosmos arose through the Big Bang .

In addition to the common matter , the stars , planets , and living creatures like us , there are dark matter , whose gravity holds galaxies and clusters of galaxies together , and dark energy , through which the expansion of space accelerates .
So far , researchers do not know which physical laws were valid in the first fractions of the Big Bang , nor what dark matter and dark energy consist of .
With " Euclid " , Esa has already approved a M mission , which is scheduled to start in 2020 .

With a special telescope , the probe is intended to examine the distribution of matter in the universe for the first time in the whole sky , thus enabling conclusions on the nature of Dark Matter and Dark Energy .
Who could Race
Of the 30 proposals , only two will remain at the end of the selection process .
In the opinion of many experts , " E-Lisa " has the best chance of being granted an L mission , a sophisticated concept for detecting gravitational waves .
Physicists understand changes in the structure of space time that Albert Einstein predicted almost 100 years ago .
They have not been proven to date .
Elisa could do that , the scientists hope behind the project .
The mission provides a detector consisting of two or three probes , which is stationed in space .
In contrast to plants on Earth , it could also show gravitational waves created by the Big Bang , providing new insights into the evolution of the cosmos .

Four other proposals are still competing for the second L mission : a large X-ray telescope called " Athena " , which is to explore black holes , " Icy Planets " , another mission to the outer planets of the solar system , " Prism " , a mission to measure the cosmic background radiation , and the " Exoplanet Finder " , which is to detect and investigate earthly planets .
Proposals for the return of the Mars , for the study of the moon , Venus and Asteroids as well as solar physics have already been excluded .

For 21 years Georges Bwelle looked at how his sick father repeatedly lost consciousness and traveled to hospitals that did not have the means to help him .
Jamef Bwelle was injured in a car accident near Youndé , the capital of Cameroon in 1981 .
At first , he had only a broken arm , but then there was an inflammation that spread to his brain , causing a hematom to affect him for the rest of his life .
“ There were no neurosurgeons in Cameroon , ” says Georges Bwelle .
We would have brought him out of Cameroon if we had had the money .
Instead , Bwelle spent years accompanying his father in overcrowded clinics and hospitals to get the treatment they had to offer .
“ It ’ s not easy , ” commented Bwave .
You can leave the house at five o 'clock in the morning and go to the hospital to be the first , and it is not the first .
There are many patients .
Some people even die because they have to wait .
The situation has hardly changed since Bwelle 's father died in 2002 .
In Cameroon , there is only one doctor per 5,000 people , according to the World Health Organisation .
On the other hand , the relationship in the United States is with a doctor for 413 people .
But even if there was a doctor for them , most cameras could not afford to visit .
Two out of five people in the country live below the poverty line , and nearly three-quarters of the country ’ s health spending is private .
“ The only problem they have is poverty , ” says Bwelle .
And poverty makes it impossible to enjoy life .
To see his father and so many of his compatriots suffer in Bwelle made the decision to do something about it mature .
Dr. Georges Bwelle and his volunteer team performed 700 free operations last year .
He became a doctor himself and works as a vascular surgeon at the Central Hospital in Youndé .
He also established a non-profit organization called ASCOVIME , which travels to rural areas on weekends and offers free medical care .
Since 2008 , he and his voluntary group have helped nearly 32,000 people .
Almost every Friday , he and up to 30 people forced themselves into minibuses and go to the villages that need help with the dirty medical equipment on the roof .
Not always everything runs smoothly .
More than once they had to push the vehicles through rivers and mud .
But when they arrive , they will be received like heroes : a feast , singing and dance , and the best accommodation the place has to offer .
In these villages , free medical care is really a reason to celebrate and shave – with its wide smile and limitless energy – is happy to celebrate .
The next morning , the team will start studying hundreds of patients .
“ We treat 500 people per ride ” , says Bwelle .
They come from a 60 km radius around the village – and that on foot .
Each of these weekend clinics offers medical care in a number of areas .
Many people are treated for malaria , tuberculosis , malnutrition , diabetes , parasites , and sexually transmitted diseases .
Others get crutches , donated glasses , or free birth certificates – a document that is needed for school , but many poor families simply cannot afford .
In the evening , the team performs simple operations with local anesthesia .
The operations usually take place in a school , a town hall or an apartment ; after the surgery , the patients are on their way to the recreation area to make room for the next one .
The lighting for the OP and the disinfection equipment is supplied by the generator of the group and so Bwave and its volunteers work until the early morning hours on Sunday .
It is a tiring pensum , but village musicians usually help keep the team motivated .
“ They are drumming all night so that we can stay awake and continue our work , ” says Bwelle .
On Sunday the team returns to the city , tired but proud of the work done .
The group – a mixture of Cameroon doctors and foreign medical students – carried out 700 free operations last year and knows that its work makes a huge difference for the people they help .
A man explained that the free operation of a barrel break that he had received now allows him to work again .
“ This changes the future of my family , ” the man said .
In addition to weekend clinics and his work as a surgeon in the hospital , Bwelle also works at private clinics in Youndé at night .
With this second job , he financed 60 % of his non-profit activity , according to Bwelle ; the rest comes from private donations .
“ I really don ’ t know when he sleeps , ” says Katie O ’ Malley , who studied medicine at Drexel University in Philadelphia in the second year and volunteered to work in Bwelles Group .

We can be involved in operations where we help to absorb blood or keep the instruments for Dr. Bwelle ,  explains O 'Malley .

At about 120 metres in length , a Roman sewage channel is preserved below Cologne .
If you visit Cologne , don 't miss the cathedral .
The two towers reach the sky about 157 metres and make it the second highest church building in Europe .
But only a few visitors , who admire the two filigree towers , know that there is also a lot to discover under the Duomo .
Rainer Schulze is an expert in matters related to Cologne 's underworld .
Meeting point for its guided tours is the service center of Cologne tourism directly at the Duomo .
The tour starts quite unspectacular : " We start in the underground car park , " says Schulze .
In the 1970s , the city ’ s fathers wanted to be an autogenous city , and that ’ s why the remains of the old city wall remained only that which was not too big .
For this reason , most users of the car park pass the Roman remains today and only leave their cars .
But if you take a closer look , you will find an archaeological site separated by metal grid rods in the Parkdeck D2 .
You can see about five meters high ruins of handmade stones .
They are remnants of the Roman city wall that was built in the second half of the first century after Christ ,  says Schulze .
Before going back to the daylight , Schulze allows participants on the upper level to take a look at a dark , 15 metres deep shaft .
This is the fountain of the old cathedral , which is unfortunately hardly seen .
The next stop of the tour is the Pretorium , where the participants descend back into the depth .
Here we see the seat of the once most powerful man north of the Alps , the preacher of the CCAA .
What CCAA means , a visitor wants to know .

The abbreviation stands for  Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium " , which means in German as much as " City of Roman Law and City of Agrippinenser , founded under Emperor Claudius at the place of the altar for the Emperor " .
And the Pretorium is the former state palace , the power center of the Roman Empire on the Rhine .
From the hall of the exhibition there is a tunnel access to the Roman sewage channel , which is preserved here at about 120 metres in length .
You can quietly walk along the so-called Cloaca Maxima , if you like ,  Schulze will delight the guests .
Schulze still has a surprise .
After he got the key at the checkout , he leads the group to a 16-meter deep walkable pit .
We are now in the Mikwe , a ritual Jewish bath ,  he explains .
The Jewish community built its bathroom deep into the ground to reach the groundwater , which was indispensable for ritual washing .
To this day , in the lower end of the Mikwe , whose origins date back to the eighth century , different water levels can be traced through changing levels of the Rhine .
